content: We at Igalia believe the Web is important to the XR space in a large number of ways. XR systems which provide an immersive OS need web browsers to be part of that. Entering a “reality” without access to everything that already exists on the Web would be pretty terrible.

content: Additionally, WebXR opens new avenues to navigate, share, and experience information driven from within the browser itself. Reimagining a browser for an immersive OS is new ground, and that newness means browser choice is currently limited.

content: Today, standalone or tethered devices for XR are the most popular options, and we believe that is important. Our first focus is on AOSP-based, stand-alone XR systems and HarmonyOS tethered systems, including: Oculus, Huawei VR Glass, HTC Vive Focus, Pico Interactive, and Lynx. We are also working with companies such as Qualcomm and Lenovo to get the browser running into their XR devices.

content: First, there is something of a tradition among browsers to have an animal association. There is, of course, Firefox. Brave has a lion as a mascot, there are Puma and Dolphin browsers, and many smaller and historical browsers and projects within the browser space are named after animals. Since our initial effort takes over where the fox left off, keeping it in the canine family felt nice, while recognizing that it will follow its own evolutionary path.

content: Furthermore, there is a metaphorical aspect to it. From Romulus and Remus in Roman mythology to Akela in the Jungle Book, wolves in mythology and literature are often shown rescuing, nurturing, and the pack protecting protagonists who turn out to play quite important roles. In practice, wolves and humans have, for millennia, had a close relationship. The first animals ever domesticated by humans, wolves have helped us get around, helped us hunt, guarded livestock, and kept us safe. Wolves are pretty unique in this regard.
